Story: I glanced at my phone during a brief lull between stations, my wife’s message lighting up the screen: “Can you talk? I really need you.” She’d been anxious all week about a big decision at work, and I knew she was counting on me to listen, to reassure her, to be the steady presence she needed. My thumb hovered over the call button, heart tugging me toward her. But just then, the cabin door slid open and my supervisor stepped in, clipboard in hand, eyes sharp. “Performance audit,” he announced, voice clipped. My pulse quickened. I was expected to be flawless now—alert, precise, every protocol followed to the letter. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing in: my wife’s vulnerability on one side, my duty as a subway operator on the other. I gripped the controls, torn, my mind racing with the impossible choice between being the husband she needed and the professional I was required to be.
